body: LATE in the evening on a mid-November Wednesday, when Union Square was dark and quiet, a mild-mannered, blue-eyed man named Eldon Scott stood near the bronze statue of George Washington with a surveyor's wheel in his hand and counted out six paces. Fishing a nub of yellow chalk from the pocket of his green zippered fleece, he stooped down to make a
title: The Jewel Box of Union Square

body: PARENTS around the city are eagerly awaiting delivery of the 5-by-7, 8-by-10 or wallet-size school portraits of their children that typically arrive in mailboxes this time of year. But instead of the stuffy, posed portraits with forced smiles and blue carpet backgrounds customary to the genre, some Brooklyn parents are getting images like these
title: THE CITY VISIBLE; Smiley Faces

body: IN September, Cathy DeVore, a real estate agent in Larchmont, N.Y., whose business has been at a standstill lately, began taking gradual steps to lay off her longtime nanny and housekeeper. Aware that the woman supports a son, a mother, and a niece in Dominica, and worried for their well-being, Mrs. DeVore wanted to make sure her employee found
title: Trickledown Downsizing

body: Open Now VINEGAR HILL HOUSE The name refers to a part of Brooklyn just west of the navy yard. That's where last week, Jean Adamson and Sam Buffa, left, opened this cozy place where the cooking is done in a roaring wood-burning oven: 72 Hudson Avenue (Water Street), Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn, (718) 522-1018. B-BAP FUSION RICE BAR Jeena Kim, a designer,
title: Off the Menu

body: LONG ISLAND COLLEGE HOSPITAL has stood at the northwestern corner of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, overlooking the harbor for 150 years, so its presence in the surrounding neighborhoods cannot be boiled down to a single anecdote. It has been there for births and deaths and the large and small crises in between: a case of a school principal with whooping
title: DISPATCHES; A Hospital That's Critical, As Neighbors Pace and Fret

body: To the Editor: A little elucidation on ''Pop'' Torello, the honoree of a somewhat cryptic brass plaque at 227 Smith Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and the subject of a question about his identity in the F.Y.I. column on Nov. 2: Living right around the corner, I, too, have been intrigued by the plaque, and in the days leading up to its 50th
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; The Bereaved Man Behind the Plaque

body: To the Editor: Re ''Trouble, Two Doors Down'' (Oct. 26), about the opening of an epicurean market on the same block as a grocery in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn: I beg to disagree with the resident who was quoted saying she doesn't ''have time to stop in three or four stores to get dinner supplies.'' There is already a unique variety of prepared foods
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Already Enough Shops, Thanks Very Much

author: E-mail: cityletters@nytimes.com
body: Editor's Note Appended Hands Point the Way to a Vanished World To the Editor: ''Hand Signals'' (The City Visible, Oct. 26), featuring Luis Mallo's photographs of passengers' hands on the subway, reminded me of the famous photographer Weegee. You can learn a greaft deal about people from body language, including the way they fold their hands.
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Expressive Hands, Jump-Rope Girls and Rival Stores

body: BARS Char No. 4 196 Smith Street (Warren Street), Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, (718) 643-2106. New York's culinary center of gravity has shifted little by little toward Brooklyn. So it's no surprise that there's a gastro-bar like Char No. 4 in Carroll Gardens, or that it might have the most encyclopedic whiskey selection in the city -- 255 at latest
title: DINING BRIEFS; Dining Briefs

body: AFTER Finola Keyes and John Wood adopted their daughter, Jillian, from China, they decided it was time for them to leave Brooklyn for the suburbs. Once they did, they couldn't wait to return. Ms. Keyes, a native of Potomac, Md., who once vowed she would never live in the suburbs as an adult, and Mr. Wood, who is from Easton, Mass., met in the
title: THE HUNT; Back in Brooklyn

body: IF you want to rent a loft in an old commercial or manufacturing building, the best place to look is in less-established neighborhoods like the South Bronx and in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bushwick, Carroll Gardens, Clinton Hill and Red Hook. Those areas are served by small local brokers as well as the larger chains. You can find listings from
title: Finding Raw Space of Your Own

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Block That Button Q. In the last mayoral election, I was refused entry to my polling place because I was wearing my four-decade-old ''Lindsay for Mayor'' button. Is that really ''electioneering''? Then what about ''Boycott Lettuce'' or ''All the Way With Adlai''? A. One person's cute history could be another's subtle hint. Maybe ''Lindsay for
title: F. Y. I.

body: IN the recent indie release ''Momma's Man,'' a young father named Mikey returns to his hometown of New York City on a business trip, and after spending a few days at his parents' house, refuses to leave. He putters around his childhood home, an old TriBeCa loft, and the vastly changed neighborhood, avoiding his wife, his job, his whole adult life.
title: The Primal Loft

body: Opening This Week CENTER CUT Jeffrey Chodorow's sprawling new steakhouse on the second floor of the Empire Hotel, opening Oct. 30, includes dishes like steak Diane, Korean short ribs, prime rib and hot-smoked king salmon: 44 West 63rd Street, (212) 956-1288. DARDANEL Turkish food, emphasizing Black Sea cuisine, including anchovies and halvah pie,
title: Off the Menu

body: FROM one angle -- say, from the corner of Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street -- downtown Brooklyn might seem to be a horrible place to live. Look over one shoulder and there's the abandoned Brooklyn House of Detention, which the city has considered revitalizing as a combination jail and multiuse project. Over the other shoulder are several lanes
title: HABITATS; Finding the Best Side of a Neighborhood

body: RUNNING a grocery is a fairly even-keel business, at least compared with, say, being a derivatives trader. You keep the shelves stocked, adjust the orders based on what's selling, advertise a sale on Tropicana orange juice every so often. Recessions come and go, but people always need groceries. And yet, Al Sale, the 54-year-old owner of Good Food
title: URBAN STUDIES; Trouble, Two Doors Down

body: IN the six years since Donna Walrond moved to Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, she has found much to like about the neighborhood. Her rent is cheap, the neighbors are friendly, and crime is decidedly down. There's just one problem. ''We have two good restaurants,'' she said the other day in the toy-strewn living room of her three-bedroom apartment on
title: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT; Her Wheels, Their Meals

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: Sometimes it seems like Facebook is the most backward-looking innovation ever expected to change the future. Especially for people who throw up only a perfunctory Facebook page, the site seems mostly useful for entree points into the past -- random hellos and what-are-you-up-tos and updates from people they once saw around campus or played kickball
title: BIG CITY; Thanks to Facebook, Your Childhood in Park Slope in the '80s Never Has to End

body: Zoe Kazan spends most evenings on a Broadway stage these days, but if she didn't, she might instead be found handing out leaflets for Save the Whales, carrying grocery bags for elderly women or looking for a losing team to console with juice boxes and cookies. And if she were to meet Masha, the terminally unhappy character she plays in ''The
title: Animating the Underdog In Film and Stage Roles

author: MATT GROSS writes the Frugal Traveler column for the Travel section.
body: AT its most generous, New York bestows a rare gift upon visitor and resident alike: it makes you feel young. Stride down its granite-steel-and-glass corridors, and your viewpoint is instantly that of a child, eyes directed forever upward. But New York offers a deeper sense of youth, too, the earnest expectation that one day, out of the blue, your
title: Frugal New York

body: WHEN the artist Byron Kim saw workers repainting a small bridge near his studio in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, he was concerned. ''I watched them painting it Deep Cool Red,'' he said, ''and I kept thinking, did we pick the right color?'' Along with having an artist's eye for particulars, Mr. Kim is one of 11 members of the city's Public Design
title: THE CITY VISIBLE; Painting the Town

body: CARROLL GARDENS DUPLEX $725,000 BROOKLYN: 62 Bergen Street (between Smith Street and Boerum Place), #2 A one-bedroom one-and-a-half-bath condominium with a large family room, a laundry area, a wood-burning fireplace and a deck, in a converted clapboard house. Terry Naini, Prudential Douglas Elliman (917) 841-1826; www.prudentialdouglaselliman.com
title: ON THE MARKET

Among the highlights on Saturday: Clint Eastwood interviewed by Lillian Ross; the
title: Spare Times

body: Korean Restaurant Week Through Saturday, nearly 20 Korean restaurants are featuring prix fixe bibimbap lunches and dinners, including appetizer and dessert, for $15 as part of Taste of Korea, the first Korean restaurant week. Bibimbap alone, $7, is available at lunch only. On Saturday at 2 p.m., bibimbap, a dish of rice and vegetables, will be
title: Calendar

body: When the third season of ''Ugly Betty'' begins on Thursday, viewers who see the show's star, America Ferrera, stumble past the Brooklyn Bridge or the Empire State Building will be seeing something new: New York. Until this season, the ABC show was produced in Los Angeles, where its exterior shots were frequently filmed in front of green screens,
title: Thanks to Tax Credits, the New York You See on TV Is More Likely the Real City

body: Opening This Week ARPEGGIO AND THE CENTER ROOM Restaurant Associates has reconfigured Avery Fisher Hall's dining options with a wine bar, Arpeggio Food and Wine, open until midnight, and the Center Room, offering pretheater buffet lunches and dinners. They are closed on Mondays: Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 874-7000. CHAR NO. 4 The name
title: OFF THE MENU

body: In just a few short days, Daniel L. Squadron has gone from neophyte insurgent candidate to wunderkind. His victory in the Democratic primary last week over State Senator Martin Connor, a 30-year veteran of Albany and onetime Senate minority leader, has made Mr. Squadron, 28, one of the most talked-about figures in New York City politics. Since that
title: His Agenda: A More Open Albany

body: OUTFITTING a nursery used to be a snap: pink for girls, blue for boys, yellow for babies whose parents were a bit more progressive. Put a crib here and a bassinet there, mount an animal mobile that plays ''Farmer in the Dell,'' and the work was done. Today, there is a wider variety of well-designed products that are sophisticated and eco-friendly.
title: SHOPPING WITH : Christiane Lemieux | Growing Room

body: THE New York event designer David Stark transforms unexpected materials, sometimes even scraps headed for the recycling bin, into works of beauty. For a National Design Awards ceremony, he once turned shredded office paper into topiary. ''I think of each project as a big art installation that happens to be for a party or a dinner,'' he said. Mr.
title: SHOPPING WITH DAVID STARK | Made With Twine

body: THESE are the rules of restaurateurship this season: be persistent and keep it simple, or get somebody else to do the heavy lifting. Restaurant openings in New York are beginning to require the kind of planning that went into the Beijing Olympics. A few of the restaurants in this annual preview were also in the preview last year, prematurely, it
title: Even Chefs Have to Wait for a Table

body: OPENING LATER ALDEA George Mendes, whose résumé includes Bouley and Wallsé, will have a menu with a Portuguese accent, with dishes like sardines and Madeira raisins, and pork chop with clams and kale. He has enlisted Stephanie Goto, who worked on Morimoto and Corton, to design sleek, intimate spaces for the narrow room with a mezzanine: 31 West
title: OPENING LATER

author: Compiled by Kris Ensminger E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: BoCoCa, a term coined several years ago for a shopping guide, refers to the junction of Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens. While it hasn't exactly caught on with the fervor of, say, TriBeCa or Dumbo, it does identify the site of a vibrant dining scene. These places have all opened in the past year or so. Black Mountain Wine House (718)
title: GOOD EATING | BOCOCA; Brooklyn Cornucopia

body: WHEN Gavin Cutler bought an 1890s Brooklyn brownstone in 2004, he knew he wanted to gut the whole thing. He envisioned the top three floors as a big, open space for himself and his companion, Sundy Procter, and the garden floor as an apartment for his sister, Anne Cutler, and her 7-year-old daughter. Mr. Cutler hired Robert Young, a Manhattan
title: ON LOCATION; Subtract Walls, Add Color

body: I was at the bottom of the ocean in Brooklyn when it dawned on me why I love New York City beaches even more than those pristine, remote shores seen in vacation brochures. It was not exactly pristine or remote where I was swimming, at Brighton Beach, surrounded by a group of elderly Russians in bathing caps backstroking their afternoon away. But as
title: SUMMER IN THE CITY; Too Darn Hot? Hop the 'Sea' Train

body: NEW Yorkers see their town as the center of the universe. But despite huge strides by New York's cafes over the last few years, the most respected coffee roasters are elsewhere. Now, some of the best are coming to town. Duane Sorenson, who owns Stumptown Coffee Roasters, based in Portland, Ore., packed up a U-Haul last month and moved to Carroll
title: Specialty Coffee Roasters Brew in New York

body: IN the early, unwashed days of punk, one fanzine published a simple poster-like manifesto that read: ''Here's three chords. Now form a band.'' For musicians who thought playing in public required lasers, smoke machines and a 20-minute guitar solo derived from a Bach cantata, nothing could have been more liberating. Eton, which opened a month ago in
title: $25 AND UNDER; Take Dumplings. Add Ice. Slurp.

body: International USING DECREE AUTHORITY, Chávez Expands His Powers President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela used decree powers that were set to expire to enact a set of measures that seem based on a package of constitutional changes that voters rejected last year. His actions significantly increase his power and are likely to open a new stage of
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: August 6, 2008

body: COULD Champagne replace beer as Brooklyn's quaff of choice? Now there's fighting words. But bartenders in this venerably beery borough seem, increasingly, to be reaching for a heavy-bottomed bottle of Champagne, rather than a long-necked bottle of beer. Not that they're pouring it, unaccompanied, into delicate flutes -- Brooklyn's gentrification
title: SHAKEN AND STIRRED; Well, It's Not Champale

Girls 8 and older are invited to have dinner at 5:30 p.m. at the cafe at American Girl Place,
title: Spare Times

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. title: Spare Times

body: The size of new buildings in an area of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, that is known for the large, elaborate gardens in front of its brownstones will be limited by a zoning change passed by the City Council on Wednesday. Because of arcane zoning rules that date to the mid-1800s, those large gardens had made the Brooklyn neighborhood susceptible to
title: New Limits On Builders In an Area Of Brooklyn

body: A lab coat sits on a rack inside the darkened Vermont Market and Pharmacy, waiting for a druggist who, by the looks of the place, has not filled a prescription in decades. Dust has settled on a generation of clutter: bills, egg cartons, newspapers and a vintage scale that provides both a horoscope and a weight for 5 cents. A sign advertises goods
title: Filling in a Few Blanks in an Old Brooklyn Real Estate Mystery

body: When the Brooklyn Brewery set up its brew house 12 years ago in a decaying section of Williamsburg riddled with empty shells of the borough's industrial past, Steve Hindy, the brewery's president, was hailed as a pioneer. Today, the neighborhood has come a long way: Condominiums a block away offer rooftop cabanas, while developers are turning
title: Double Edge to Brooklyn's Success

body: AROUND TOWN VICTORIAN GARDENS AND ASTROLAND AMUSEMENT PARK New York may never sleep, but it certainly gets sluggish this time of year. Yes, we know, there's the Siren Festival, Warm-Up at P.S. 1, Central Park SummerStage and countless other chances to test the impact of alcohol consumption and sweating like a hog on your hydration. Those of us not
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Every Friday and Saturday at 7:30 and 8:30 p.m., ''SonicVision,'' an animated alternative-music show is shown in the Rose Center; tickets, $15; $12 for members. Tuesday at 6:30 p.m., ''Mint Julep: The Official Drink of the Kentucky Derby,'' a
title: Spare Times

body: SET back from President Street in Carroll Gardens, in the shadow of a large brick church -- once Congregational, now condominiums -- there is a small Romanesque Revival building that gets a lot of attention from Brooklynites. Unlike other distinctive-but-diminutive New York structures that are squashed between larger neighbors, this one luxuriates
title: WHO LIVES THERE; The Church Ladies' Parlor

body: To the Editor: Re ''Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn,'' July 16: I have lived in the Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill, Boerum Hill neighborhood (sorry, I refuse to call it Bococa) for 23 years. We used to have to travel to Park Slope or Bay Ridge to find something okayish to eat. Since Jim Mamary and Alan Harding opened Patois and began the Smith
title: Brooklyn Pioneers

body: It is easy to forget, in celebrating the suspension of street-cleaning parking rules, that such an act is accompanied by the suspension of, well, street cleaning. The absence of those lumbering scritchy-scratch street sweepers has not gone unnoticed in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where a two-month hiatus from alternate-side parking rules has created an
title: Parking Rules Return; Cleaner Streets to Follow

body: WITH a trunk full of cod, brisket, blackberries, arugula and antifreeze, Alan Harding drives down Smith Street, past American Apparel, past the Michelin-starred restaurant Saul and past Patois, the bistro he helped open 11 years ago. Back then the neighborhood was a more likely destination for drug deals than dinner. Patois, where he was the chef,
title: Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn

body: Late one night, shortly after Kai Lui and his wife, Laura Campbell-Lui, moved into their Queen Anne-style house in Midwood, Brooklyn, she shook him awake, insisting that she heard intruders. Mr. Lui went to investigate and discovered noises coming from the fourth-floor attic. He called the police. ''They had their weapons drawn,'' said Mr. Lui, a
title: The City's Latest Real Estate Fight: Humans Against Raccoons

body: To the Editor: I must disagree with Michael Collins, who in a letter published on June 29 suggested that the author of ''A Circle of Women, Discovered on a Stoop'' (New York Observed, June 22) was actually stealing when she picked up a Rumer Godden novel from the steps of a Brooklyn Heights brownstone. Maybe where Mr. Collins lives, in Chelsea,
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Ladders of Memory and a House With a Past | In Brownstone Brooklyn, Stoops Are For Recycling

body: They were ready to pour the concrete for the fifth floor of a luxury condominium building in Lower Manhattan when more than 400 concrete-truck drivers went on strike. So the concrete waits to be poured and the number of carpenters and other workers at the site fell from 75 on Tuesday to 50 on Wednesday. The number is expected to plunge to 15 on
title: Drivers' Walkout Has Ripple Effect Across City

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites 'SUPERHEROES: FASHION AND FANTASY' LECTURE AND PANEL ''Shakespeare is not writing any new plays, but he's taught in classes everywhere. Comics may stop publishing tomorrow, but people can still study comics.'' So says Peter Coogan, the author of ''Superhero: The Secret Origin of a Genre.'' He founded the Institute for
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. title: Spare Times

body: NEW PLACE South Brooklyn Pizza 451 Court Street (Fourth Place), Carroll Gardens; (718) 852-6018. New Yorkers who love pizza will endure a lot to get a good one, like standing in line for an hour outside Totonno's Pizzeria Napolitano or watching the time pass as Domenico DeMarco at Di Fara slowly hand-grates cheese, pizza by pizza. This behavior can
title: DINING BRIEFS; South Brooklyn Pizza

body: They may be calm and gentle, and perhaps a bit droll. But those voices emanating from WNYC, New York City's top public radio station, also have the power to whip up a fervid following. So when WNYC announced that it would sell bric-a-brac from its old studios as it prepares to move to new ones, and that many of its longtime hosts and reporters
title: WNYC Star Power Helps Make a Sale

body: -- 84 degrees in Central Park at 6 p.m., 85 at La Guardia Airport. But New York was cooler than it was on Monday or Tuesday, and it felt less like a giant, hair-frizzing, shirt-ruining steam bath, the kind of thing Ethel Merman or Marilyn Monroe sang about -- take your pick -- ''We're having a heat wave, a tropical heat wave.'' William Vega, a bus
title: The Day New York Found That Its Fever Had Broken

body: The Way It Was Today Barney Greengrass will celebrate its 100th anniversary by serving food in the restaurant, not the retail store, at prices from 1908, like a herring plate for 60 cents, chopped liver for 75 cents and a sturgeon sandwich for $1.75. The store opened at 113th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, and moved to its present location, 541
title: Calendar

body: For working stiffs, the fun in the sun ended on Monday. After two days of toying with the stifling weather in shorts and T-shirts, they found the most mundane chores a challenge during record-high temperatures in the New York region. The early-season swelter created an array of problems, from power failures to delays on several subway lines.
title: In a Sweltering City, Any Sliver of Shade Will Do

body: Doctors at a community hospital in Brooklyn that is part of a large system of hospitals say they are being squeezed out so the system can sell off property in popular neighborhoods. The doctors contend that the parent company, Continuum Health Partners, has been downsizing the institution where they work, Long Island College Hospital, in the Cobble
title: Doctors Say Hospital Is Falling Victim to Its Own Real Estate Value

body: IN 1846, the City of Brooklyn passed a law requiring that front yards along certain streets in Carroll Gardens be 33 feet 5 1/4 inches deep. In time, the big yards were responsible for the name of the neighborhood, and for its reputation as a fine place to view Christmas lights during the holidays. But most recently, those trademark gardens have
title: CARROLL GARDENS; The Big Front Yards That Rob the Streets

author: Tom Vanderbilt's book ''Traffic: Why We Drive the Way We Do (and What It Says About Us)'' will be published in July by Knopf.
body: IT was late morning, a few Sundays ago. My wife and I were returning to Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, via car, from tea and scones in Greenwich Village. At the approach to the intersection of Chambers and Centre Streets, right next to City Hall Park and close to the entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge, we pulled up to a line of cars stopped at the light.
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Out of Nowhere, A Thud, and Then Blood

body: ANDREA STRONG assumed she would remain in her 350-square-foot fourth-floor studio near Stuyvesant Square in Manhattan ''for all of my days.'' It was a great deal. After 10 years, she paid a monthly rent of about $1,300 for the rent-stabilized unit. For those 10 years, Ms. Strong had been a regular at the local coffee shop, 71 Irving Place. She
title: THE HUNT; A Sweet Deal

body: FOR Maggie Tobin and Bob Mason, the last straw in Park Slope was the parking. The couple, who have two young children, lived there for eight years and loved being near Prospect Park and surrounded by friends. But when the time came to buy, they wanted more space and found the prices too high, and they decided they could also live without the ritual
title: LIVING IN KENSINGTON, BROOKLYN; Name From London, People From Everywhere

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: If you will excuse a biblical flourish, the G train is the Moses of New York mass transit. Like Moses, it never made it to the Promised Land. That is, if Manhattan is your idea of divine promise. With its nosebleed-inducing apartment prices and rents, some think of it as flowing not so much with milk and honey as with bilk and money. In any event,
title: NYC; Rallying Round a Train That Gets No Respect

title: The Listings

body: To the Editor: ''In City's Growing Neighborhoods, Public Schools Face Pupil Jam'' (front page, May 9) describes the latest twist in New York City's school facilities crisis. In 1988 the New York State Legislature, before creating the School Construction Authority, found that ''many of the schools are overcrowded, unsafe, unhealthy and unusable.''
title: LETTERS; The Woes of New York's Public Schools

body: KERMIT WESTERGAARD grew up on the Upper East Side, far from hammers and paintbrushes. Yet early on, he was seized by the idea of renovating a historic house for himself. Last year, he got the chance when he and his wife, Azadeh, bought a 1908 row house in Ridgewood, Queens, for $592,000, and turned it into their comfortable fantasy of a simple
title: HABITATS | RIDGEWOOD, QUEENS; A 'Farmhouse' Near the L Train

body: EVIDENCE suggests that New Yorkers may be more religiously observant now than three decades ago. The number of churches, temples, mosques and other houses of worship -- many of them in storefronts -- jumped by 37 percent in Manhattan from 1980 to 2000, according to census data. In Brooklyn during the same period, the jump was a whopping 87 percent.
title: POSTING; Brooklyn Churches Come and Go

body: FOR CHILDREN ASTRONOMY DAY On Sunday Mike Francis will bring ''Siderius Nuncius'' to life. To children that may sound like a mythological creature, a Frankenstein-like monster or some other fearsome invention by a mad scientist. But ''Siderius Nuncius'' was created by an eminently rational scientist: Galileo, whom Mr. Francis, above, has been
title: Spare Times: For Children

It's meant for casual dining but offers some dressy touches, like chandeliers, in a brick and wood setting. The menu emphasizes
title: Off the Menu

body: NEW PLACES Turqua Grill 9604 Third Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. (718) 238-8885. The action in the shadow of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge at the far end of Bay Ridge is a delightful, and recent, surprise. Valets work for several restaurants at once, while a constant flow of diners dips in for a fancy cupcake here or a plate of good spaghetti and
title: DINING BRIEFS; Dining Briefs

body: The JakeWalk 282 Smith Street (Sackett Street) Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, (347) 599-0294. The JakeWalk is a counterpoint to Manhattan's conspicuously chic enotecas, less a wine bar than a friendly neighborhood bar with over 200 wines. There's a wait for the candlelit tables at night, when the flocked wallpaper, the only nod to décor, takes on a
title: DINING BRIEFS

body: They are both amputees: She lost part of her right leg to bone cancer at the age of 10, and he lost part of his left leg four months ago because of an injury he most likely suffered at a Brooklyn slaughterhouse. Her name is Jenny Brown, and she is a 36-year-old television producer turned animal rights advocate. His name is Albie, and he is a goat
title: A Rescued Goat Gets a Chance For a Normal Life On Four Legs

body: ON any given evening in Carroll Gardens, several neighborhood denizens will stop on Brooklyn's bustling Smith Street in front of the JakeWalk's large picture window, peering into the smallish, packed rectangular bar. body: Twenty-five years ago, a lot of creative downtown types looking for alternative credentials and low overhead costs became performance artists, setting up shop in cheap lofts in all-but-deserted neighborhoods (making a performance of one's own sleep deprivation -- also low-cost). The 2008 version of that same crowd seems to be leaning toward an art

body: IT was a Wednesday night around 7:30 and Casellula, a small, boxy wine bar in Clinton, was filling up. Patrons packed the seats at the small polished wood bar and the inexpensive wood tables, trading sips of wine, sharing beautifully composed cheese selections and passing plates back and forth. No sharing for me, though. My open sandwich, made with
title: Wine Bars Grow Up and Squeeze In

body: Those Shoes, Those Bags To the Editor: Julia Allison, and her contemporaries who have fawned over ''Sex and the City'' and shaped their perception of reality around it (''Channeling Carrie,'' March 30), have contributed to making dating in New York all but intolerable. This personifies their shallow materialistic existence and need for overpriced
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; The Tragically Hip, and Civic Hard Times

body: Two men were killed in Brooklyn in separate encounters, the police said on Tuesday. In the first, Sanjeev Seekoomar, 34, was found on Tuesday morning stabbed to death in his basement apartment at 326 Carroll Street in Carroll Gardens, the police said. The door to the apartment was pushed in and the apartment ransacked, indicating a possible
title: Killings in 2 Brooklyn Neighborhoods

title: Spare Times

body: MOST New Yorkers would greet the prospect of a $51,000 two-bedroom co-op in Chelsea with slack-jawed wonder, since the average price for an apartment in the city now exceeds $1.4 million. They might react the same way to a three-story house in Park Slope priced at $255,000 or to a one-bedroom in a brand-new Harlem condominium for $147,500. But
title: Winning That One In a Million

body: BERNIE DeCHANT owns a two-family house in a nice San Francisco neighborhood. His buddy Pascal Balthrop owns a three-story town house in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. title: HABITATS | CARROLL GARDENS; Reluctant Landlords Settle Into a Rental

body: FOR New York basketball fans, 33 is either a famous or an infamous number, depending on your age. If you're over 20, you can probably remember when the Knicks were ruled by Patrick Ewing, the dominant center with a blazing 33 on his chest. Younger fans may be more likely to associate 33 with the number of games a miserable Knicks team won last
title: Any Given Monday

title: LETTER; The Rising Popularity Of Queens

body: To the Editor: Like Nathaniel Rich (''His City, Lost and Found,'' Feb. 3), I am a city kid displaced in my own city. When I am asked the obligatory ''So, where are you from?'' I answer: ''I'm from here. I grew up in the Village.'' The reply is always: ''Really? I never meet anyone from here.'' Since we are middle-class and well educated, you can't
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Remembering a City They Hoped Would Be Theirs

body: Usually, it is the harsh yellow of the crime scene tape that catches the eye, its cold, crisp snap in the wind a universally understood sign of recent unpleasantness. title: DITMAS PARK JOURNAL; Betting on Cuisine to Marginalize Crime

body: WALKING along Adelphi Street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, you could almost miss The Hideout, and not just because the former parking garage doesn't have a sign. body: ON Jan. 2, commuters in and around New York City woke up and celebrated the new year by going back to work. On that day and every workday since, I have been commuting with them, traveling in and out of the city to write an online series called Next Stop for The New York Times about how people get to their jobs and what they think of the ritual they
title: Commuting: The Ferocity And the Fun

title: Metropolitan Diary

title: HABITATS; An Idiosyncratic Gem In Carroll Gardens

title: THE HUNT; Quiet on the Home Front

body: Salvatore Bklyn Ricotta sounds tough, but it's actually a delicacy, from the kitchens of Lunetta in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. Betsy Devine, far left, a sous-chef at the restaurant, and Rachel Mark, near left, who works for a wine importer, learned the craft in Tuscany from Salvatore Farina, who makes it for his wine bar in San Gimignano. title: FOOD STUFF; A Creamy Tuscan Ricotta, Made Fresh in Brooklyn
